repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
vim.ui.open "locks up" Nvim if the spawned process does not terminate. #27986

Solution:
- Change `vim.ui.open()`:
    - Do not call `wait()`.
    - Return a `SystemObj`. The caller can decide if it wants to `wait()`.
- Change `gx` to `wait()` only a short time.
    - Allows `gx` to show a message if the command fails, without the risk of waiting forever.


Fix #27986

comment_data.body: Checking `signal` to detect "timeout" seems hacky. Should we expose a `timeout=true` flag (or some other "status") on the `wait()` result?  @lewis6991
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -94,10 +94,19 @@ do
     { silent = true, expr = true, desc = ':help v_@-default' }
   )
 
-  --- Map |gx| to call |vim.ui.open| on the identifier under the cursor
+  --- Map |gx| to call |vim.ui.open| on the <cfile> at cursor.
   do
     local function do_open(uri)
-      local _, err = vim.ui.open(uri)
+      local cmd, err = vim.ui.open(uri)
+      local rv = cmd and cmd:wait(1000) or nil
+      if cmd and rv then
+        if rv.signal and rv.signal ~= 0 then
+          err = ('vim.ui.open: command timeout: %s'):format(vim.inspect(cmd.cmd))

comment_data.body:
Expose `cmd` on `SystemObj`, because it's a basic info that may be needed by consumers (which didn't necessarily originate the `system()` invocation). @lewis6991 

I also wonder if `vim.SystemObj` and `vim.SystemCompleted` should be one interface.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -321,7 +324,7 @@ function M.run(cmd, opts, on_exit)
   --- @type vim.SystemState
   local state = {
     done = false,
-    cmd = cmd,
+    cmd = vim.deepcopy(cmd),

comment_data.body: Maybe we can do better than this pattern. Need to think carefully about https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/19624
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -114,14 +114,19 @@ end
 --- Examples:
 ---
 --- ```lua
+--- -- Asynchronous.
 --- vim.ui.open("https://neovim.io/")
 --- vim.ui.open("~/path/to/file")
---- vim.ui.open("$VIMRUNTIME")
+--- -- Synchronous (wait until the process exits).
+--- local cmd, err = vim.ui.open("$VIMRUNTIME")
+--- if cmd then
+---   cmd:wait()
+--- end

comment_data.body: Can revert this if wanted. LMK
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -321,7 +324,7 @@ function M.run(cmd, opts, on_exit)
   --- @type vim.SystemState
   local state = {
     done = false,
-    cmd = cmd,
+    cmd = vim.deepcopy(cmd),

comment_data.body:
> I also wonder if vim.SystemObj and vim.SystemCompleted should be one interface.

I don't think so personally. Each object is mutually exclusive to the other. Merging them together just creates more entropy since each field would become optional, and I generally prefer return types to be as predictable as possible (i.e. avoid returning possible nils).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -321,7 +324,7 @@ function M.run(cmd, opts, on_exit)
   --- @type vim.SystemState
   local state = {
     done = false,
-    cmd = cmd,
+    cmd = vim.deepcopy(cmd),

comment_data.body:
> Expose cmd on SystemObj, because it's a basic info that may be needed by consumers (which didn't necessarily originate the system() invocation). @lewis6991

As long as there's a concrete use case, then it makes sense. What's the use case here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -321,7 +324,7 @@ function M.run(cmd, opts, on_exit)
   --- @type vim.SystemState
   local state = {
     done = false,
-    cmd = cmd,
+    cmd = vim.deepcopy(cmd),

comment_data.body: Use-case is that vim.ui.open returns a SystemObj and the caller (`gx` mapping) wants to print info about the command that was run.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -321,7 +324,7 @@ function M.run(cmd, opts, on_exit)
   --- @type vim.SystemState
   local state = {
     done = false,
-    cmd = cmd,
+    cmd = vim.deepcopy(cmd),

comment_data.body: Is it even sound since the signal could have originated from somewhere else? We could add a `timeout` field to `SystemCompleted`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -94,10 +94,19 @@ do
     { silent = true, expr = true, desc = ':help v_@-default' }
   )
 
-  --- Map |gx| to call |vim.ui.open| on the identifier under the cursor
+  --- Map |gx| to call |vim.ui.open| on the <cfile> at cursor.
   do
     local function do_open(uri)
-      local _, err = vim.ui.open(uri)
+      local cmd, err = vim.ui.open(uri)
+      local rv = cmd and cmd:wait(1000) or nil
+      if cmd and rv then
+        if rv.signal and rv.signal ~= 0 then
+          err = ('vim.ui.open: command timeout: %s'):format(vim.inspect(cmd.cmd))

comment_data.body:
Hence "hacky" :) Just noticed that code=124 on timeout? https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/1d73ecda7f9be51371096989e5f1b351caf55d83/runtime/lua/vim/_system.lua#L283

Any reason not to set it to -1 (analogous to `jobwait()`)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

     { silent = true, expr = true, desc = ':help v_@-default' }
   )
 
-  --- Map |gx| to call |vim.ui.open| on the identifier under the cursor
+  --- Map |gx| to call |vim.ui.open| on the <cfile> at cursor.
   do
     local function do_open(uri)
-      local _, err = vim.ui.open(uri)
+      local cmd, err = vim.ui.open(uri)
+      local rv = cmd and cmd:wait(1000) or nil
+      if cmd and rv then
+        if rv.signal and rv.signal ~= 0 then
+          err = ('vim.ui.open: command timeout: %s'):format(vim.inspect(cmd.cmd))

title: fix(vim.ui): open() may wait indefinitely
